intro: Acer negundo var. texanum, commonly known as the Texas maple, is a deciduous tree native to the southern United States. It typically grows to a height of 15–25 feet and has a rounded, spreading crown. The leaves are palmately lobed, with five to seven pointed lobes, and turn yellow in the fall. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in early spring, followed by winged samaras. This species is adapted to a variety of soil types and is often found in moist, well-drained areas.
